abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Water Supply Project in
            Liberia was sufficient. The International Development
            Association (IDA)'s performance was adequate, and
            played an instrumental role in establishing and maintaining
            a very productive working relationship with the implementing
            agency, and the Gesellschaft fur Technische Zusammenarbeit
            (GTZ). The experience from this project gives rise to a set
            of questions which are easy to ask in retrospect but
            difficult to answer. Why attempt a miniscule rescue
            operation in the midst of severe country and sector problems
            and at a time when other Bank's financed projects, with
            reinforcing objectives, such as the Structural Adjustment
            Credit, were on hold? Given that the Bank Group was not
            obligated to disburse funds if the Government of Liberia
            (GOL) and the Liberia Water and Sewer Corporation (LWSC) did
            not comply with its legal covenants, why did the Bank/IDA
            not stop all disbursements sooner and cancel the remainder
            of the credit? One lesson that can be derived from this
            project's experience is that success is very difficult
            to achieve and sustain under adverse policy and
            institutional conditions.
